BE11:19am

Based on our analysis of over 150 rules on the Federal register (link here), we believe that the FDA is unlikely to publish a rule banning menthol cigs over the next 12 months. As a result, we do not expect any menthol ban to impact at retail until 2024-25, much later than our earlier published estimate of 2022-23. US tobacco stocks – BAT, MO and IMB – had weakened by ~15% in Nov 2018 when the FDA first announced its intention to propose a rule banning menthol cigs, considering menthol cigs are ~35% of the US cig market. We think this delayed timeline will start attracting investors again as regulatory headwinds ease. We reiterate our OW rating on MO ($64 PT), BATS (4000p PT) and IMB (3000p PT).

Tom Dalgleish ASX returns a disclaimer page stating that commercial access is disallowed but blocks all automated access for any purpose in the same action
red yes i think mkt ahead of itself predicting demise of smoking overnight. bit like the us economy. unless jobs data tragic this afternoon, mkt in for a bit of a shock
BE11:20am

Tom Dalgleish Aussie administrators of anything are the worst in the world
BE11:20am

As we have published earlier, the FDA rule-making process is a 9-step process, with each step taking at least 2 months. Currently, we are still on step 3 of the process when it comes to menthol cig ban – 8 months after the FDA announced its intention to propose a menthol cig ban rule - and likely to remain on this step over the next 12 months. Post the publication of the final rule (step 9), we expect litigation to take another 2 years, and another one year post litigation for the ban to become effective at retail. Thus, if the FDA were to publish a menthol cig rule in late 2020, we expect it to impact at retail in 2024-25.

Based on bottom-up analysis, we still expect US
Profit Nicotine profit pool to grow 4% (CAGR18-25) driven by resilient
cigarettes profit pool (2% with volume -5%, unchanged). As a result, our
MT profit forecast for the tobacco names are unchanged though we raise
by c2% FY19 due to FX. We continue to expect companies to miss their
MT NGP targets, but see resilient global nicotine profit growth (JPMe
+5%) to lead to a re-rating. We see recent share price pressure as overdone
and expect the group to rerate in the wake of upcoming catalysts (BATS to
reiterate FY target, PMI to see iQOS uptick in EU). We prefer BATS.

red u still see an awful lot of folks smoking, especially the celebs which the sm lemmings tend to follow
Tax Realist aggregator and reseller, good at IT too to help with the parsing
BE11:23am

 US profit resilient despite recent negative news. While we now expect
a weak H119E, we just slightly reduce our 19E cigarettes volume
growth (-4.8% vs -4.4% earlier), but we see revenues +1% due to
stronger pricing. We foresee: US cigarettes profit pool resilient with 2%
profit growth CAGR18-25. If adult smokers switching rate accelerates
(suggested by Altria) this would equate to a 100bps downside risk on
cigarettes volume, less than feared by the market.
 US NGP dynamics not as disruptive as market believes. Following
the FDA activity in Nov-2018, vapor growth decelerated. We forecast
20% volume growth in 2019E (vs +38% in 2018) as the lower underage
take-up is offset by adult vapers inflows. US Nielsen tracker confirms
BATS share gains while IMB vapor growth turned negative. While
iQOS PMTA is positive, we have conservative estimates on heated
tobacco in the US given the unattractive economics and the different
taste profile of US smokers.

BE11:37am

888 held a Capital Markets Event on Tuesday, covering a broad range of topics including; Strategy, Marketing, Technology, the Orbit platform, and Responsible Gaming. Reflecting on this event, we upgrade 888 to Overweight (from Neutral), primarily due to increasing confidence in the structural growth prospects of Casino and Sport, exceptional near-term revenue trends in the UK (disclosed at the CME), and a (still) compelling valuation despite the cumulative c.17% run up in shares over the past three days. We leave our Dec 2019 price target unchanged at 220p, and have not materially changed our nearterm estimates.

BE11:37am

The turnaround in the UK is confirmed, with both Casino (+45% LFL May YTD) and Sport (+28% LFL YTD) driving a strong overall UK B2C performance of +24% LFL YTD. We calculate that UK B2C revenue growth in the first seven weeks of Q219 could be as high as 21%/52% sequentially/yoy. The mass-market strategy is paying off, as 888 has succeeded in shifting the UK customer base abruptly away from VIPs towards recreational players (VIP share now less than 10% vs 35-40% previously), which positions it for more sustainable growth.

den Thanks for the Purp info BE

11:38 am
BE11:38am

FY19E will likely be the trough for earnings owing to a number of well-documented cost headwinds, including the gaming duty increases (UK, Italy, Romania), US P&L investment and the integration of BetBright, as well as revenue declines in B2B and Poker. However, the online gambling model entails high operating leverage, and so continued robust B2C LFL growth (+9% 2019 YTD) will eventually drop through to EBITDA. In addition, BetBright net costs (currently c. $3.5m) will reduce as Kambi is phased out and, depending on the pace of state openings in the US, net P&L investment of c. $8m per annum should discontinue. We also expect declines in B2B and Poker to moderate significantly in FY20E.

Tax Realist @Tom, its workflow efficient and because we parse, we also database and that can help show trends over time.

Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 10.61, up 0.21 (+2.02%), High: 10.68, Low: 10.39, Volume: 251.33k
BE11:40am

Wizz has materially outperformed Ryanair & easyJet over the last 12 months. While Wizz has benefitted from its strong position in and exposure to faster growing Central & Eastern European markets, and ability to main its ultra-low cost base, Ryanair & easyJet have been struggling for three main reasons: (i) a weaker pricing environment in Western Europe (pockets of overcapacity, eg. in Germany / Austria; low consumer confidence, eg. in the UK); (ii) start-up losses (in Tegel; at Laudamotion) and tough comparatives from when Air Berlin & Monarch ceased operations, together with higher staff costs at Ryanair; and (iii) material unit fuel cost headwinds, which the previous two points have made it impossible to offset, resulting in profit declines vs growth at Wizz

SGE has made good progress in transitioning to a subscription revenue model. However, we foresee recurring revenue growth slowing from here as some of the initial boost factors from a subscription transition fade.We believe that SGE is now entering a new phase, where the quick wins from low-hanging fruit are fading, and the company now needs to focus on organic product development to sustain growth in the future. In our view, this will unavoidably result in a sustained rise in SGE's historically low level of R&D investment and operating margin pressure.

BE11:52am

It was a hot day, and we were on the highway, a water bottle full of Soylent between us. Rhinehart had invited me to accompany him on a trip to El Segundo, to meet another food technologist: Ethan Brown, the C.E.O. of Beyond Meat, a company that uses the protein found in peas and soy to make chicken and beef substitutes. Brown had stationed a food truck outside a Whole Foods, where he was giving away tacos. The food truck had a party atmosphere: soul music played from speakers, and venders called out, “Free tacos!” Whole Foods shoppers stopped to stare. The truck had a sign on it: “real meat. 100% Plant Based Protein.”

Here's them:

BE11:55am

Following BYND’s first earnings as a public company, we are raising our estimates, reiterating our Overweight rating and boosting our price target to $120 from $97. At some point, the extraordinary revenue and profit potential embedded in BYND – as we highlighted in our initiation, “A Big Juicy TAMBurger” – will be priced in. But our updated DCF valuation indicates 21% upside from yesterday’s closing price of $99.50. Importantly, when discussing guidance, CEO Ethan Brown said, “We’re being very conservative” and let investors know that no foodservice customers are included in guidance until they are past the testing stage. Again, eventually this stock’s hefty valuation will more than offset the fast-growing fundamentals, in our mind. But until then, and as long as Street forecasts fail to properly reflect BYND’s remarkable potential, we remain Overweight.

Omikin I wonder how profitable Quorn is? Seems overpriced compared to competitors.
Jamie Powell (FT Alphaville) @DutchBrat -- don't joke, gross margins already better than Tesla's
Tom Dalgleish @BE, hence Michelin numbers to distinguish a menu
BE11:56am

The margin expansion story remains underappreciated. Not only did 1Q19 EBITDA exceed the pre-announced range, but also guidance for 2019 EBITDA came in at “break-even” versus consensus -$5MM (a big difference for a company of this size). Management said today it expects
to ultimately reach a gross margin in the mid 30% range; however, it already is approaching 27%. We see no reason why the gross margin cannot get to at least 40% to 50% all else equal; however, management wants to reinvest heavily in price before letting this happen, and thus we cap it at 36% long-term. When skeptical investors ask how BYND plans on attacking approaching competition, we think they may overlook the flexibility the company has to invest in price. Our TAM model that points to a $5B ultimate revenue opportunity presumes that BYND’s prices to retail customers drop by 35% over time.

A. M. (Modern life is trying to imitate 70s dystopias. What's not to like)
#REF! If prefer pdfminer (and tabula for tables)

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Even our higher 2019 estimates may be conservative. Guidance calls for revenue to exceed $210MM; we model $233MM but it is conceivable that Tim Horton’s alone (a current customer with nearly 5,000 locations that is not yet in guidance) could account for most of that gap. In addition, we only model $2MM in EBITDA, which is not far from the “break-even” guidance that relies on $210MM in revenue. For 2020, we model sales growth slowing to 60% from 165%, which may be conservative if a major customer or two were added (or if sales to European and Asian retailers expand rapidly). And we assume that 2020 operating margin growth slows from +2,700 basis points to +800 bps despite meaningful low-hanging fruit ahead from continued scale benefits and help from higher average prices (thanks to mix).

Dec69 - Skeptic Come on! JPM's "But our updated DCF valuation indicates 21% upside from yesterday’s closing price of $99.50. " At such a stage in its cycle one can only guess and at this valuation with a break-even event achieves even on US multiples $40

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

BYND's shares now trade at ~15.5x FY21 EV/sales vs. 4.1x/4.8x for consumer growth companies/FRPT. We view BYND's mgmt as extremely capable and the growth stor perhaps the best in staples; however, our DCF analysis suggests greater than 25% 10-yr sales CAGR/ramp to ~+15% EBITDA margin discounted in the stock. Sustaining said CAGR is plausible should the US plant-based protein market grow 20% and BYND attains ~17% market share. That said, it also carries risks, particularly with competition likely to ramp up (i.e., TSN/NESN, potential Impossible US retail launch, etc.). Based on our upwardly revised growth est, we lift our PT to $105 (from $85) based on 50/50 DCF and 16-17x EV/2Q20 NTM sales multiple.

strophe PVCS rise is just a share consolidation. Nothing to get excited about.

I see there's a certain amount of pushback to that JPM note. So, let's spin back to its initiation!

BE12:01pm

Back end of last month.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

And brace yourself.

A. M. (@TomD: well, maybe recent advances in hydroponics (are there?) might give it a boost. something useful ought to come out of the weed revolution)
BE12:02pm

Beyond Meat is a true disruptor and innovator. Los Angeles, CA–based Beyond Meat is a leader in the production and marketing of plant-based meat. The Beyond Burger, its flagship product, is unlike traditional veggie burgers; it has been scientifically designed to replicate ground beef from plant protein. Shelf placement is also unique: products (burgers, sausages, etc.) are commonly sold in the meat case, juxtaposed with animal-based meat, rather than freezers. Consumer response in both grocers and restaurants has been highly encouraging, with Beyond’s revenue growing at an accelerating pace: 84% in 2016, 101% in 2017, 170% in 2018, and ~200% in 1Q19.
 We think plant-based meat can exceed $100 billion in sales in 15 years, with Beyond taking 5%. We strive to be conservative in this model. We assume, for instance, that a) only 2/3 of meat is addressable by plant-based options and b) plant-based meat’s share maxes out at 10% (versus 13% already for US plant-based dairy, a figure growing each year). Within this context, we believe it is reasonable to think BYND’s revenue can hit $5B in 15 years, based on our top-down and bottom-up analyses. We do not believe this opportunity is fully priced in, despite the rally post-IPO.
 The near-term margin and cash flow stories are underappreciated. Investors seem focused on Beyond’s revenue potential, with good reason, but they often overlook an impressive bottom-line opportunity. Thanks primarily to scale benefits, Beyond’s gross margin improved by 3,200+ basis points in 2017 and ~2,700 in 2018.
We model another 1,500+ over the next three years. We also see EBITDA turning positive by the end of this year. In other words, Beyond is not a startup that can sell a lot of product but make no money; it is a legitimate manufacturer that, in our view, has a clear path to bottom-line and cash flow success.

BE12:03pm

What we have here is from the "it's a potential market worth [silly number] so even if they only take a small bit of it, it's still going to be worth [percentage of silly number]" school of research.
